fields.description:
we have proved that updating the label & description of custom field scheme may bring "Perform Reindexing" warning bar shown in Administration pages .

We should only show it when having a concrete "issue type" or "project context" change on custom field scheme.
fields.summary: "Require Perform Reindexing" Warning Message should not Show Up When Only Changing Label & Desc of Custom Field Scheme

2. There is non-clickable space between the Component combo-box arrow and the border that surrounds the text field. I expect there to be no space.
3. I am not sure I like the new Component combo-box as input. Specifically, I am concerned that selecting and deselecting multiple items is slower. 4. If you decide to keep the current combo-box approach I suggest changing the combo-box into a "+" arrow since the box only adds items, not replace the existing values.

fields.description:
The documentation on [Making a project "Read-Only|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Archiving+a+Project#ArchivingaProject-Makingaproject%27ReadOnly%27] should have warn user that, the their user still able to execute certain Workflow Transition in the project if the user met the Transition's Condition. 

Here is an example situation:
If a transition(eg: Start Progress) has a condition "Only Assignee will be able to execute this transition", the issue's Assignee will be able to execute the transition even though the assignee does not have any permission other than "Browse Project" permission.

So, to prevent the user from able to execute any transition the Workflow Transition's Condition must be modified. A recommended way is to add a Permission Condition (any permission as long as not "Browse Project")to all of the transitions available.
fields.summary: Making a project "Read-Only" should warn user to edit the workflow transition in order to prevent users from executing any transition

fields.description:
I like the use of line separators between custom fields, especially when there are a number of them. It greatly improves readability.

I see that they are not used if there are less than 5 fields. The real problems are caused by wrapping when either the field name or the value takes up more than one line. Without line separators this degrades readability, even with only two or three fields. I think the lines should always be present. This is more consistent as well as more readable, although it does potentially take up unnecessary space.

In cases where multiple tabs are used, I like the way the tab header acts as a boundary between the standard "details" fields and custom fields. I wonder if a line should be placed above the first custom field to provide the same boundary when there are no tabs. The line would be the same weight as used in the collapsible headers.
fields.summary: Displaying multiple custom fields

fields.description:
The "Create Issue" link launches a Javascript pop-up. That pop-up appears to have a timer attached to it that will close the pop-up if the mouse moves off of it for more than 10 seconds. As it turns out, IE is treating hovering over the project select list as if you had moused off of the pop-up.  So, it starts the 10 second timer once you click on the project select list.  If you haven't made your selection by the end of the 10 seconds, the pop-up disappears.  

Replication Instructions:
# Click on the Create Issue link in the upper right-hand corner of the JIRA GUI 
# Click into the Project list
# Scroll down a few projects but don't actually select anything
# The popup box closes if you haven't made a selection in about 10 seconds
# This happens in IE (v8x) but not FF (v3.5.10)
fields.summary: "Create Issue" link has a timeout in IE

fields.description:
On the new Jira view issue screen, the only difference between a field label 'Affects Version/s:' and field data e.g. '2.0.0, 2.0.1' is that field labels are grey and field data is black.  That is way to subtle.  If these were more differentiable the UI would be much more easier and faster to use.  I could scan it quickly for fields I am interested in and then hone in on the data.  Right now they blend together making digesting a Jira issue slower than it needs to be.

Strangely the headers for field sections are colored and easily differentiable, but what people need to see quickly are the field labels, not the headers.  e.g. I look for a particular field, not section headers.

http://skitch.com/cbrookins/dpr5i/box-1-allow-mapping-of-fix-version-fields-for-bulk-move-feedback.onjira.com-jira

fields.description:
On IE 7, when the description field of a component contain certain characters, this component do not show up in issue statistics gadget by component (dashboard) or the name of the component do not show up. It works on Firefox.


{quote}
We have about 15 to 20 components in one project and we are doing an issue statistics gadget by component, listing. Some components do not show up.
Actually, I figured out the problem...

If the component description contains a certain set of characters then it causes the component name to hide from dashboard:issue statistics gadget. Only in IE, Firefox and Chrome do not have this problem.

Failed descriptions (Exact description within Quotes):
"There was an issue with the credit card. I.E It couldn't "

Working description:
"There was an issue with the credit card. I.E It couldn't"

These are the three descriptions that were failing for me, all had an ending space. If there is a short description with a space at the end, the dashboard works properly.

"There was an issue with the credit card. I.E It couldn't be read by the card reader, it was being declined etc. "

"issue came about because the unit didn't have power. It may not be plugged into the wall or the PC was turned off (this would also be hardware). "

"Any technical issue that we come across I.E Unit is frozen, stuck in a boot process, not all the channels show up, internet browser issues, etc. "
{quote}
fields.summary: name of the project do not show up in issue statistics gadget by component when the description field of the component contains certain characters

fields.description:
In some circumstances it may be helpful to be able to read back through the issue at hand in order to add the correct information to the screen in the workflow action. 
Instead of asking the user to perform 2 actions - comment and update status - we prefer to do all actions within one step. Because the system currently brings up workflow action screens in the current window, users are unable to read back through the original issue to help them with their present action. 

This can of course be easily accomplished by opening another window to view the issue but a pop-up would be a much better and user friendly alternative. 

I think it would be nice if we could define the required behavior in the workflow action or screen definition. Another option would be to allow users to select the behavior for their environment in the profile configuration.
fields.summary: Enable pop-up windows for workflow action screens

fields.description:

Hi,

Currently when you compare dates using the JQL the only supported format is the american date format.
For example: project = OTU AND issuetype in (Incidències, Peticions, Consultes) and  tri<trf

fields.description:
Hello,
at today when visualising an issue it is possible to expand/collpase description and comments. 

This allows to handle long text comments leaving the issue readable

The expand/collapse option is not available for the stream visualisation, therefore it suffices one very long comment added to an issue (like comments created automatically strting from an email) to make the stream completely unreadable

it would be nice to have the feature expand/collapse avaialble also for the stream visualisation

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21755].
  {panel}

Steps to reproduce:

# View a bunch of issues from all different projects so that they are in your history
# Select an issue from a project which is not a sub task and choose the action "Convert to Sub Task"
# Instead of typing in the text field to use the AJAX issue picker, click the "select issue" link to the right
# A popup opens; observe the issues presented in your "history"

The history contains issues which are from other projects, as well as issues which are themselves sub tasks, and even the currently selected issue. None of these issues could possibly be a parent for the chosen issue. The list of issues from the current search correctly filters out these issues, but the "history" list does not.

The user shouldn't have the option to select something which will result in a validation error upon submitting.
fields.summary: Issue Picker popup for Convert to Sub Task should only show issues which are eligible to be parents of the chosen issue

fields.description:
We'd like to use Jira as a toll to manage our team and office's "Workplan".

I work in a central government CIO Office...we'd like to use Jira to enable our stakeholders to recomend workitems and vote them up in the same way Jira is being used for crowd sourced software development....however some terminlogy related to software development (issue and versions namely) are critical barriers to use for this application. Our stakehodlers are regular non-tech people...
 Two sub issues:

1) The ability to change the work "Issue" or anything or something more relevent would remove the blocker for our use.

2) Our office does work on versions and release schedules...we have a rolling workplan...unscheduled...scheduled (accepted or scheduled work)...complete (history of what has been done...so we don't do it again)...we typically write reports, business specifications, standards and strategies.

I think Jira could be a more capabile and accessable general project management tool (for non-software development appliactions) with these and other changes
fields.summary: Ability to customise terminalogy: i.e. Issue -> Work Item

fields.description: The problem is that we design systems for 911 call centers and would like to make the incoming 911 trunks the first several line appearances on the phone.  The issue is that the Polycom 670 assumes that all lines can be dialed outbound (which is not the case with 911 trunks which can only be used for incoming calls) and automatically grabs the first line appearance when the handset in taken off-hook.  To temporarily solve the problem we were forced to put the 911 lines appearances last on the phone which is not at all ideal for a 911 call center.  If a configuration setting could be added to specify which line appearance (or group of line appearances) to use when the handset is taken hook-off that would solve the issue.
fields.summary: SoundPoint 670 - Line Appearance Selection on Off-Hook

fields.description: My company had use JIRA for years, we use the 'Components' to  represent our product's components. But we hadn't use the 'Cascading Select' custome field. Now we need to divide up the components to 'components' and 'sub-components'. We have 100000 issues now. If we use 'Cascading Select' now,we can't divide up the components in the existed 100000 issues.So I wonder if there is a way to auto-generate the sub-components. Such as, when we select the conponent 'ADM-Content Manager',it will generate a custome field(read-only) which values 'Administration'. Is that possible?

fields.description:
The datevalue field of the customfieldvalue table occasionally contains values such as {{0008-06-13 10:09:24-05:50:36}} which, while technically valid, send JIRA into conniptions and cause pre-upgrade backups to fail with messages such as this:
{noformat}org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericDataSourceException: SQL Exception while
getting value:  (Bad value for type timestamp : 0008-06-1310:09:24-05:50:36)
org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: Bad value for type timestamp :0008-06-13 10:09:24-05:50:36
Caused by: java.lang.NumberFormatException: Trailing junk on timestamp: ''
       at org.postgresql.jdbc2.TimestampUtils.loadCalendar(TimestampUtils.java:226){noformat}

Even if we can't do anything about external libraries choking on the retrieve values, can we add some validation logic to ensure the correct value is stored?
fields.summary: Insane but technically valid values in the datevalue field of the customfieldvalue table

Hi, 

when uploading a file using phpBB to a forum, first the file is uploaded.

Bye,
Michi

Hi all,
one of the statistics the test department is interested is the number of closed issues, as this is one of the metrics they need to know. To support the traceability it would nice to get the following two gadgets on the dashboard:

Manuel Kohler
ACS Bern
manuel.kohler@acs-inc.com

fields.description:
I need something that is like Workload Pie Chart, but the data comes from Work Log instead. My problem with Workload Pie Chart is that it uses the Time Spent field of each Issue and associate that with the assignee of the Issue. It does not work with the way we are using JIRA.

An example is this:

We create JIRA Issues for certain meetings (Team meeting, Iteration meetings, etc). The assignee of these meetings is the organizer of the meeting. Other people going to these meetings usually log their hours against these Issues. 

In the Workload Pie Chart, all the hours logged against the meeting Issues will be shown under the assignee of the Issues, not the logger of the Work Log.
fields.summary: Need Work Log Pie Chart

fields.description:
We are developing a SOAP web client for JIRA that allows our customers to create support issues. Customers can also add attachments to issues. We are using the SOAP API call addBase64EncodedAttachmentsToIssue(...) to accomplish this. The attachments are added to the issues correctly and everything seems to work fine.

However, after adding an attachment, memory does not seem to be freed correctly in Jira. Looking at the Memory Graph in the Administration Section, more and more memory is eaten up for every attachment added. First after clicking "Force garbage collection", the memory usage returns to normal.

We discovered this issue when suddenly no more JVM memory was available and uploading attachments failed. Currently using -Xms512m -Xmx768m as inut args to the JVM.
fields.summary: addBase64EncodedAttachmentsToIssue also runs out of memory

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21714].
  {panel}

I don't know if it's just me. I get exited when I hear Mike Cannon-Brookes speak about doing things for all us customers, and granted, I am a satisfied customer. However, when I see what's on the roadmap, I see a lot of new features, but not a lot of attention to issues that are already in the support site for a long time, and they just don't seem to get any love anymore from Jira product management.
I have heard that you seem to be driven by Votes, but even that is not a good approach for reviewing the long open issues, some of which add functionality we all need, but now need to hack the system for to get working. If we can hack the system to make it work, how difficult would it be for some "catch-up developers" to add some of the long open feature/improvement requests we've already submitted?
I want to plead for an effort in Atlassian when the great new things have their roadmap, but where there is also a catch-up development team who will add features we've submitted and which haven't had much love lately (like sometimes years!).
Jira Product Management, what say you?
fields.summary: Review long open issues with feature requests

{code:java}
searchRequestManager.getAll().foreach(new SharedEntityGroupUpdator<SearchRequest>(oldName, newName, filterPermissions));
{code}

is throwing the following exception:

{noformat}
com.atlassian.jira.exception.DataAccessException: com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.JqlParseException:com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.antlr.RuntimeRecognitionException: MismatchedSetException(46!=null)

	at com.atlassian.jira.studio.importer.StudioImport.doImport(StudioImport.java:100)
...
Caused by: com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.JqlParseException: com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.antlr.RuntimeRecognitionException: MismatchedSetException(46!=null)
	at com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.DefaultJqlQueryParser.parseClause(DefaultJqlQueryParser.java:135)
	at com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.DefaultJqlQueryParser.parseQuery(DefaultJqlQueryParser.java:37)

	at com.atlassian.jira.ProxyAdapter$ProxiedComponentInvocationHandler.invoke(ProxyAdapter.java:167)
	at $Proxy141.parseQuery(Unknown Source)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.OfBizSearchRequestStore.getSearchQueryFromGv(OfBizSearchRequestStore.java:410)
	... 122 more
Caused by: com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.antlr.RuntimeRecognitionException: MismatchedSetException(46!=null)
	at com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.antlr.LexerErrorHelper.handleError(LexerErrorHelper.java:54)
	at com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.antlr.JqlLexer.recover(JqlLexer.java:121)
	at com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.antlr.JqlLexer.recover(JqlLexer.java:127)
	at com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.antlr.JqlLexer.mERROR_RESERVED(JqlLexer.java:1511)
	at com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.antlr.JqlLexer.mTokens(JqlLexer.java:2207)
	at org.antlr.runtime.Lexer.nextToken(Lexer.java:84)
	at org.antlr.runtime.CommonTokenStream.fillBuffer(CommonTokenStream.java:119)
	at org.antlr.runtime.CommonTokenStream.LT(CommonTokenStream.java:238)
	at com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.antlr.JqlParser.query(JqlParser.java:191)
	at com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.DefaultJqlQueryParser.parseClause(DefaultJqlQueryParser.java:124)
	... 129 more
Caused by: MismatchedSetException(46!=null)
	at com.atlassian.jira.jql.parser.antlr.JqlLexer.recover(JqlLexer.java:126)
	... 136 more

{noformat}

It would appear that one of the filters being loaded has invalid JQL.  I don't think this should stop them from being loaded from the database by the {{DatabaseIterable}} though.  This error occurred after a fresh JIRA import (that's probably how the corrupt filter got in there), during the Studio import process.
\\
\\
*Cause*
An invalid character gets stored into *searchrequest* the database, for example the query is stored like this:
{code}
fixVersion = 3.0
{code}
* this causes problems as JIRA cannot properly parse the 3.0

Instead, what should be stored is:
{code}
fixVersion = "3.0"
{code}
* It is not known how the JQL gets improperly stored into the db
fields.summary: JqlParseException thrown by foreach method of DatabaseIterable over all search filters

fields.description:
Hi there!
We need multiply actions for issues. 

The case is: an issue (of type "feature" for ex) after work has done, gets state "approving". Then, a group of stakeholders should receive notification, and they all should make "acceptance" of that issue. Stakeholders can include, for ex, issue's creator, business owner ('s), project manager, change manager. All of these people should do an action ("sign", or "endorse"), which means "yes, I agree with implementing of feature, we can implement it into production". The issue will change it's state only after all of stakeholders had made their actions. After that issue gets state "implementing in production". 

If there is some workaround of this feature, it will be very good.

ps: why different states for each approving are not acceptable: there can be many people in one role (for ex, several business owners), and their ALL should sign an issue. I didn't found how to make it by standard JIRA's tools
fields.summary: Implement multiply action for issues
Add user preference to display new comment instead of issue

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21703].
  {panel}

The word "Translate," in this case, means translate the statuses from one language to another, but that's unclear from the context, and especially unclear to first-time users, who are still trying to figure out what statuses and steps are. Furthermore, I would guess that this feature isn't used by very many users. These point toward clarifying the wording on this link.

We could do two things, I think:
1) Change "Translate statuses" to "Translate statuses to a different language"
2) Move the link to a less prominent part of the UI, and perhaps attach some country flags to the link so people understand it's referring to languages.
fields.summary: Move "Translate statuses" to less prominent area of the user interface

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-21696].
  {panel}

When a user has no issues and no projects in JIRA, they are probably a new user who is unsure about how to use the product, especially for users who are evaluating the product. The "No issues found" screen is fairly important and a chance for us to explain JIRA's functionality in more detail. Currently these screens are fairly empty. I've attached screenshots of some of the important screens.

This could be a very simple fix. For example, the screen that says 

"You have no favourite filters at the moment" 

could be rewritten to say 

"You have no favourite filters. [Learn more about filters|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Saving+Searches+('Issue+Filters')] or [create a new filter]." 

We provide the user with an opportunity to learn more about the product and use the product in a beneficial way, and introduce him/her to the documentation. Furthermore, the cost to existing users is extremely low, as the screens disappear as soon as they begin creating projects.
fields.summary: Improve text on blank screens - "No issues found," "No projects found," etc.
